awd_titl_txt: REU Site: Back to the Future
awd_abstract_narration:
NON-TECHNICAL DESCRIPTION: The National Science Foundation 'Back to the Future' Research Experience for Undergraduates Site at the South Dakota School of Mines and Technology will expose a diverse group of undergraduate students, including Native American students and women, to the research environment and to help them develop as professionals. The focus of the student research is the study of metals and metal production, an area of vital technological importance to national interest in areas of defense, manufacturing, resource utilization, and energy. Students will also participate in research projects with the National Park Service focused on the preservation and analysis of historical artifacts as well as activities that highlight the importance of metals throughout history, hence, the 'Back to the Future' theme. This context will give students a broader appreciation for the nature of current and future research as well as the impact of engineering in society. 

TECHNICAL DESCRIPTION: The REU Site: Back to the Future at the South Dakota School of Mines and Technology is a 10-week summer project that will provide research opportunities in metallurgical and materials engineering that enhance the global competitiveness of the nation in the areas of advanced materials and manufacturing, mineral beneficiation and resource recovery, strategic metals, and energy-efficient materials. The project will address challenges faced by future engineers by providing a research experience within a unique cultural and holistic framework. This framework will be provided by teaming with the National Parks Service on research that has historical significance and innovative activities led by faculty from engineering, science and the humanities that explore the interface between engineering, history, and art (the Back to the Future theme). Students will participate in an integrated supplemental training program that nurtures their research skills and career development. This program includes advanced technical communications training, workshops and seminars to give historical context for current trends in research, as well as activities that connect students to each other and the community. The diverse nature of program activities will attract students of varied background and intellectual typology. The Site will provide opportunities for underserved students in engineering with an emphasis on two-year community and Tribal Colleges from the region. The site will also strengthen ongoing Native American NSF initiatives in the region including All Nations Louis Stokes, Tiospaye, and the Oglala Lakota College / South Dakota State University / South Dakota School of Mines Pre-Engineering Education Collaborative (OSSPEC). 

This site is supported by the Department of Defense in partnership with the NSF REU program.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
The NSF Research Experience for Undergraduates (REU) “Back to the Future Site” at the South Dakota School of Mines is an integrated 10-week summer research program focused in Metallurgical Engineering.  Undergraduate students from many engineering and science disciplines work with a team of faculty mentors on important topics in Metallurgical Engineering including advanced alloy development, materials joining, biomaterials, nanotechnology, mineral processing, microstructural characterization, and corrosion engineering.  Many of these topics have the potential for far-reaching impact in terms of public welfare by improving manufacturing of advanced alloys and bolstering domestic development and sustainability of important natural resources.  Many of the projects also have important historical implications through a partnership with the National Park Service Submerged Resources Center to better understand the degradation of submerged resources such as the USS Arizona. 

In addition to conducting research, students participate in a highly advanced professional development program with technical seminars on global trends in metallurgy and an integrated technical communications program.  Students are particularly encouraged to publish or present their research at a regional or national conferences such that over 50% of all students have disseminated their research findings over the lifetime of the grant.

Engineering faculty have also teamed with faculty from the humanities and local artisans to develop supplemental workshops and activities that showcase the impact of metallurgy on history and art to provide a unique historical framework for current research, hence the “Back to the Future” theme.  These activities have included artistic metal working, blacksmithing, and metal casting.  Figure 1 shows an example of one such workshop where the REU students participated in a historical workshop on Metal in Native American Art and Culture led by Lakota Artist Mr. Jhon Goes in Center.

During the project period, the REU Back to the Future Site team continued to lead a yearly statewide “South Dakota Undergraduate Research Symposium” that has grown to over 150 students from many REU and other undergraduate programs across the state.  Figure 2 is an image from the symposium which shows that the South Dakota symposium mirrors the format of a national student conference poster session. The symposium has included guest speakers from the National Science Foundation and South Dakota graduate programs.

Assessment data shows very positive perception of the program and a positive impact on student gains in research skills.  Of particular note is the strong gain in technical communications from the integrated communications program.  The program has successfully engaged a diverse student population.   Nearly 20% of participants were Native American and 40% of participants were women.   Evidence from the literature suggests that a richer learning environment may be created in engineering by providing this context in the liberal arts.  The site assessment data on student typology suggests that the unique nature of site supplemental activities (focused on the historic, artistic, and cultural impacts of metals) may help to attract and retain students from underrepresented groups.  In addition, the unique learning environment may help to enhance educational opportunities for students of different learning styles or typologies.

Student retention in engineering fields and entrance into graduate school are also key indicators of program success. All REU alumni have one follow-up contact per year.  We successfully introduced an REU Back to the Future group page resulting in an impressive 90% response rate for a recent career path survey of all students.  Retention in STEM disciplines is over 98%.  As of March 2021, 106 students have graduated.  Of these graduates, 58% are attending or attended graduate or medical school, 42% are working full-time in STEM industries or teaching in STEM fields.   Participation in the program has had positive impacts on student preparation for graduate school highlighted by one Goldwater Fellow in the last period.
